values: Junior history major Matthew Simone studies for his midterms in the reading room at the Student Learning Center Thursday. He has three tests today and expected to study for them until at least midnight. While he feels overwhelmed, he offers advice to other students who are in similar situations: "Don't fall behind in the reading." Thursday marked the official midpoint of the semester, and the official midpoint withdrawal deadline is Tuesday.

The following are from our weekly entertainment section. I found the layout to be so horrendous and the picture selection so less than stellar that I told them not to put my name on it. Here is a sampling of the crap they ran (with the exception of the portrait. That was actually a good picture that ran too small).

Junior shortstop Matthew Dunn throws the ball during a play in the top of the second inning during Tuesday's game against Mercer. Dunn scored one of Georgia's three runs and had two hits in four at bats. UGA won 3-1 in the 11th inning. Cups are stacked on the counter at Fuel Coffee Cafe. Employee Lee Goins enjoys working there. "A lot of very different, interesting people come," he said.

Retiring president and vice president of the student government association This did not turn out well in the paper. The original color picture was awesome. This is of a professor/bartender doing her thing. I hate newsprint.
Photo illustration for International Condom Day.
A portrait of Miss UGA, Deondra Rose, for a profile piece that ran on the front. A Gymdog in mid bar-action.

Sophomore Erin Mahone discusses the controversy surrounding part of an exhibit in Myers Hall devoted to Charlayne Hunter-Gault at an NAACP meeting Thursday night. "Until the University of Georgia stops having these race relation issues in the news every week, our welcoming environment is going to continue to go downhill," she said. -I had a good time at this shoot. It was a last-minute deal, but well worth it. Lots of other media there. I gave out my card to an AJC reporter. It was a fascinating informal debate about history and racial sensitivity. Strangely enough, I had a dream that night that black people hate me. Maybe I was just channeling the anxiety of the white housing authority at the meeting who made the mistake of saying "some of my best friends are black."
This is from a business dining and ettiquette seminar. Students learned how to shake hands and pass salad dressing in polite company. It freaked me out just a little.
Miss UGA 2005 - Deondra Rose. She will be the subject of my new photo documentary about beauty pageants.

I went up onto the catwalk suspended from the ceiling of the colosseum to take this shot. I had a dozen pictures that were far superior. My editor choses this. Sigh. To add insult to injury, the edited version didn't make it to the layout department, so they printed the uncontrasted version, which ended up looking like shit as the dominant image on the front page of the paper.

Just a picture of the Lady Dogs for the front page in anticipation of the game against Florida tonight. This is Shadisha Robinson, one of UGA's tennis stars. I think she's ranked 10th in the country or something.
candlelight vigil held for a man to be executed by the state.

Today's paper was a little upsetting. They sent me around town the day before to shoot a bunch of pictures of Athens landmarks so they could make a collage for dominant art. They send me to shoot buildings a whole lot. Buildings are boring. Anyhow, they didn't do the collage and ended up putting a nonsensical picture of the Georgia Theater I took as dominant art. What made matters worse was that there was no cutline for it. People came up to me throughout the day to ask what it meant. Ineptitude all around, folks. We'll get over it. I hope. This was a crap follow up to the first tsunami garage sale picture. This is the actual garage sale in progress. I had a lot of good pictures from this event, but unfortunately, when I got the names of the ladies I shot as I was leaving, I was asked not to print their names or pictures in the paper because they were Jehovah's Witnesses and didn't want to be publicly associated with an event that donated money to the Red Cross. They don't support the organization because they don't believe in giving blood. This was a fantastic picture that should have run dominant. We got trounced by Kentucky and this shot really shows that. They were showboating toward the end and making slam dunks, much to the chagrin of the Georgia fans. The faces of the fans in the background are what make this picture, but they ran it way too small to the point where you couldn't distinguish any of the expressions. I was sad. Oh well. I might add that all three of these pictures ran on the front page today. Honestly, I think that's overkill.

(The ones in color are front page photos) This one was my first dominant A1 picture, and I was a little sad it was so mediocre. It was for a piece on changing the name of the stadium. This one kind of sucked too. It was for a piece on a Tsunami garage sale fundraiser and the people hadn't accumulated much stuff at that point. The Love Shack was set on fire and I had to cover it. I was one of maybe two photojournalists in the world on scene to cover this event which made international headlines. This was a cool picture, but it was a shot of a girl warming up. We won the game, so the better choice would have been an action shot, but the editor wanted to take a chance. He got chewed out for it. This was for a story on a new building. I got to play around a construction site and hang out with UGA's lead architect. He looked a whole lot like Richard Gere. For a story on the freshman Gym Dogs. These girls are awesome. This is an oldie but a goodie. This is Alice Kinman's campaign staff and supporters at the moment of her win. She is in the center clapping.
This dude scared the bejesus outta me.

I decided to start posting my pictures that make it into the Red and Black, since a lot of friends and family have been having a hard time seeing the pictures on the actual website. The first one is from a football game against Ga. Southern, and the second one is a picture I took to accompany a bar review.
Here're a bunch of snapshots from a party I attended. These are for the people who know what IFB means. For the rest of you.... keep on walkin'. And my personal favorite:
It's been a while since I posted, and Christ knows I'm either taking or editing pictures every waking second, so here's a picture to tide y'all over.

It's been awhile. Here y'all go. Little known fact: 4th of July parades open time portals that allow crazy shit like this to happen. There was a very strong military theme going on. These Marines looked so damn young.
I wanted a hardboiled egg today, but I had already put my egg boiling pot into storage. The microwave seemed like a good idea. Tragedy ensued.
Much like the vending machines for used schoolgirl panties that they have in Japan, north Georgia has vending machines for live bait. Creepy mountain children catching and torturing sucker fish.
At City Bar Mike, the attractive, fun-loving bartender at City Bar On the Street with the Economist The Economist attracts the right kind of men

Here are some of the pictures I took yesterday at the State Botanical Gardens. I had to shrink them down substantially so I could put them on the internet. The original images are spectacular in their detail. With the compression here, you lose a lot of that, but enjoy anyway.
